title: Headache Evaluation
scope: ** Systematic evaluation and diagnostic workup of undifferentiated headache in adults. Covers red flag identification (SNOOP mnemonic), primary vs secondary headache classification, indications for neuroimaging and lumbar puncture, and initial symptomatic management during workup. This is a DIAGNOSTIC EVALUATION plan, not a treatment plan for a specific headache type. Once a specific diagnosis is established, transition to the appropriate condition-specific plan (migraine, cluster headache, SAH, meningitis, etc.).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Rule out anemia, infection, thrombocytopenia; baseline before LP
Electrolyte abnormalities, renal function, hepatic function; metabolic causes of headache
Pregnancy status affects imaging choices (CT radiation) and treatment options
Screen for giant cell arteritis if age >50, new headache, temporal tenderness
Essential/Core Labs.target: <20 mm/hr (age-adjusted: age/2 for men; (age+10)/2 for women)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Inflammatory marker; supports GCA evaluation; infection screen
Baseline before LP; assess bleeding risk in suspected hemorrhage

Extended Workup.rationale: Thyroid dysfunction can cause or exacerbate headache
Low magnesium associated with headache disorders; may guide supplementation
Deficiency associated with chronic headache disorders
Differentiate bacterial vs viral etiology when meningitis suspected
If meningitis or systemic infection suspected; obtain before antibiotics
Sepsis screen if infectious etiology suspected
Carbon monoxide poisoning can present as headache; especially with multiple household members affected

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If vasculitis or autoimmune cause suspected
If cerebral venous thrombosis suspected (young patient, risk factors)
Paroxysmal headache with hypertension, diaphoresis, palpitations
If neurosyphilis suspected (risk factors, cranial neuropathies)
If immunosuppression suspected; opportunistic CNS infections
If endemic area and cranial neuropathy, meningitis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Diagnose elevated ICP (IIH) or low pressure (CSF leak/spontaneous intracranial hypotension)
Lumbar Puncture.target: 10-20 cm H2O (elevated >25 suggests IIH; <6 suggests low-pressure headache)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Detect infection (WBC), hemorrhage (RBC); tube 1 vs 4 comparison for traumatic vs true hemorrhage
Lumbar Puncture.target: WBC <5/uL; RBC 0; clearing RBC count (traumatic tap) vs stable (SAH)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in infection, inflammation, malignancy, GBS
Low CSF/serum ratio in bacterial meningitis, TB meningitis, malignancy
Detect SAH when CT head negative; xanthochromia develops 2-12 hours after bleed
Identify bacterial pathogen in suspected meningitis
Rapid multiplex PCR for bacterial, viral, fungal pathogens
Suspected leptomeningeal carcinomatosis (progressive headache, cranial neuropathies, known malignancy)
Suspected MS or other demyelinating disease
Suspected TB meningitis (subacute headache, basilar meningitis, immunocompromised)

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate if: thunderclap headache, worst headache of life, focal neurologic deficits, altered mental status, papilledema, anticoagulated patient, trauma, immunocompromised, fever with meningismus
Essential/First-line.target: Rule out hemorrhage, mass, hydrocephalus, midline shift
Essential/First-line.contraindications: None in emergency; pregnancy relative (discuss risk/benefit)

Essential/First-line.timing: New headache pattern, progressive headache, persistent headache without clear primary diagnosis, abnormal neurologic exam without acute emergency
Essential/First-line.target: Rule out mass, demyelination, Chiari, structural cause

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Extended.timing: Suspected mass, infection, inflammation, leptomeningeal disease, pituitary pathology
Extended.target: Rule out enhancing lesion, abscess, meningeal enhancement

Extended.timing: Thunderclap headache with negative CT; suspected aneurysm, dissection, or vasculopathy
Suspected cervical artery dissection (neck pain, Horner syndrome, young stroke)
Suspected vasculopathy, aneurysm, vasculitis (non-emergent or contrast contraindicated)
Extended.target: Normal vasculature; no aneurysm, stenosis, or irregularity

Extended.timing: Suspected cerebral venous thrombosis (headache + papilledema, pregnancy/postpartum, hypercoagulable state, OCP use)
Suspected cervical artery dissection (when CTA contraindicated)
If MRI unavailable and mass or infection suspected
Before administering triptans, DHE, or antiemetics (QTc assessment)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Suspected CNS vasculitis with negative noninvasive imaging; confirmed aneurysm for intervention planning
Rare/Specialized.target: Vessel wall irregularity, beading (vasculitis); aneurysm morphology

Rare/Specialized.timing: Suspected intracranial vasculitis, RCVS, or dissection when CTA/MRA inconclusive
Headache with pulsatile tinnitus, suspected CSF leak, skull base pathology
Rare/Specialized.target: Rule out tegmen dehiscence, mastoid disease

Rare/Specialized.item: Fundoscopic exam / Optic nerve sheath ultrasound
Rare/Specialized.timing: Screen for papilledema when fundoscopy unavailable or pupil dilation contraindicated
Rare/Specialized.target: Optic nerve sheath diameter <5 mm (normal); >5.8 mm suggests elevated ICP

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consult for headache with focal neurologic deficits, abnormal imaging, or diagnostic uncertainty requiring urgent subspecialty input
Neurosurgery consult for suspected SAH, acute hydrocephalus, or mass lesion with herniation risk requiring surgical evaluation
Ophthalmology consult for papilledema, visual loss, or suspected IIH requiring fundoscopic evaluation and visual field testing
Headache specialist referral for chronic or recurrent headache not responding to initial management within 4-6 weeks
Infectious disease consult for suspected CNS infection with unusual organism profile or immunocompromised host
Rheumatology consult for suspected CNS vasculitis or giant cell arteritis requiring temporal artery biopsy coordination
Pain management referral for chronic refractory headache not responding to first-line and second-line therapies
Behavioral health referral for comorbid anxiety or depression contributing to headache chronification
ENT referral for headache with sinus symptoms, pulsatile tinnitus, or suspected CSF leak from skull base

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if headache becomes the worst headache of your life, sudden thunderclap onset, or associated with fever, stiff neck, confusion, weakness, double vision, or seizure (these may indicate a life-threatening cause)
Keep a headache diary documenting frequency, severity (0-10), location, duration, associated symptoms, triggers, and medications taken with response (essential for diagnosis and management)
Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while headache is severe or if experiencing visual changes, dizziness, or sedation from medications
Avoid medication overuse: limit acute headache medications to no more than 2-3 days per week to prevent medication overuse headache
Follow up with primary care or neurology within 1-2 weeks if headache is new or within 4-6 weeks if chronic, to review diagnostic results and establish ongoing management
Bring a list of all medications (prescription and over-the-counter) to follow-up visits, including how often each headache medication is used per month

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Maintain regular sleep schedule (7-8 hours nightly at consistent times) as both sleep deprivation and oversleeping are common headache triggers
Stay well-hydrated (64+ oz water daily) as dehydration is a modifiable headache trigger
Regular aerobic exercise (30 minutes, 5 days/week) to reduce headache frequency through endorphin release and stress reduction
Stress management techniques (progressive muscle relaxation, deep breathing, biofeedback, or cognitive behavioral therapy) to reduce stress-related headache triggers
Limit caffeine to consistent moderate intake (<200 mg/day) and avoid abrupt caffeine withdrawal which can trigger rebound headache
Screen for and address modifiable risk factors: obesity, poor sleep hygiene, excessive screen time, poor posture, jaw clenching/bruxism
Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk and improve overall headache outcomes

differential.features: Unilateral, pulsating, 4-72h, nausea/vomiting, photo/phonophobia, aura in 25%, aggravated by activity
differential.tests: Clinical history (ICHD-3 criteria); diagnosis of exclusion; normal neuroimaging

differential.features: Bilateral, pressing/tightening, mild-moderate, no nausea, no photo AND phonophobia together, not worsened by activity
differential.tests: Clinical history; no imaging needed if typical presentation

differential.features: Strictly unilateral periorbital, autonomic features (lacrimation, rhinorrhea, ptosis, miosis), 15-180 min attacks, circadian pattern, male predominance
differential.tests: Clinical pattern; MRI brain with pituitary views to rule out structural cause

differential.features: Thunderclap onset (peak intensity <1 min), "worst headache of life," neck stiffness, loss of consciousness, sentinel leak
differential.tests: CT head (>95% sensitivity within 6h); LP with xanthochromia if CT negative within 6-12h; CTA for aneurysm

differential.features: Fever, neck stiffness, altered mental status (classic triad in <50%); headache, photophobia, Kernig/Brudzinski signs
differential.tests: LP with CSF pleocytosis, elevated protein, low glucose; blood cultures; CSF Gram stain and culture

differential.features: Fever, headache, photophobia, neck stiffness; encephalitis adds confusion, seizures, focal deficits
differential.tests: LP with lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal glucose; CSF PCR panel; MRI (temporal lobe in HSV)

differential.features: Papilledema, visual obscurations, pulsatile tinnitus, worse supine, typically young obese women
differential.tests: LP with elevated opening pressure (>25 cm H2O); MRI with empty sella, optic nerve sheath distension; MRV to exclude CVT

differential.features: Progressive headache, seizures, focal deficits; risk factors (OCP, pregnancy/postpartum, hypercoagulable state)
differential.tests: MRV or CT venogram (filling defect in venous sinus); D-dimer (negative may exclude)

differential.features: Age >50, new headache, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, visual symptoms, polymyalgia rheumatica
differential.tests: ESR/CRP markedly elevated; temporal artery biopsy (gold standard); temporal artery ultrasound (halo sign)

differential.features: Unilateral head/neck/face pain, partial Horner syndrome, pulsatile tinnitus; history of trauma, chiropractic manipulation, or connective tissue disorder
differential.tests: CTA neck or MRA neck with fat-sat; intimal flap, pseudoaneurysm, or string sign

differential.features: Recurrent thunderclap headaches over 1-4 weeks, may have triggers (vasoactive drugs, postpartum, exertion, Valsalva)
differential.tests: CTA/MRA with segmental vasoconstriction (beading); resolves within 3 months; catheter angiography if noninvasive negative

differential.features: Progressive headache, worse in morning or with Valsalva, new focal deficits, weight loss, seizures
differential.tests: MRI brain with contrast; CT if MRI unavailable

differential.features: Orthostatic headache (worse upright, better supine), may have subdural collections, pachymeningeal enhancement
differential.tests: LP with low opening pressure (<6 cm H2O); MRI with diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement, brain sagging; CT myelogram to localize CSF leak

differential.features: Headache with nausea, dizziness, confusion; multiple household members affected; worse in winter (heating systems)
Chronic daily headache (>15 days/month) in patient with pre-existing headache disorder using acute medications >10-15 days/month for >3 months
differential.tests: Medication diary; improves with withdrawal of offending agent (within 2 months)

differential.features: Severe eye pain, headache, nausea/vomiting, mid-dilated fixed pupil, red eye, visual halos, elevated intraocular pressure
differential.tests: Intraocular pressure measurement; slit-lamp exam; gonioscopy

differential.features: Severe headache with SBP >180 and/or DBP >120 with end-organ damage (encephalopathy, visual changes, AKI)
differential.tests: Blood pressure measurement; fundoscopy (papilledema, hemorrhages); renal function; CT head to exclude hemorrhage

differential.features: Sudden severe headache, visual field deficits (bitemporal hemianopia), ophthalmoplegia, altered mental status; history of pituitary adenoma
differential.tests: MRI with pituitary protocol; hormonal panel (cortisol, TSH, prolactin, GH)

monitoring.frequency: Per assessment; q1-2h in ED; q4h inpatient; each visit OPD
monitoring.action: Escalate analgesic regimen; reassess for secondary cause if not improving

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (mental status, cranial nerves, motor, sensory, coordination)
monitoring.frequency: At presentation and with any change; q4h if admitted; each visit OPD
monitoring.action: Urgent imaging and neurology consult if new deficit; reassess differential

monitoring.item: Vital signs (BP, HR, RR, T, SpO2)
monitoring.frequency: Per assessment; q1h in ED/ICU; q4h inpatient
monitoring.action: Address hypertensive urgency; fever workup if new; reassess for infection

monitoring.frequency: At presentation and q1-2h if declining; q4h if stable inpatient
monitoring.action: Urgent imaging; ICU transfer if GCS declining; intubation if GCS <8

monitoring.frequency: At presentation and q2-4h if concern for elevated ICP
monitoring.action: Fixed dilated pupil = emergent imaging + neurosurgery; initiate herniation protocol

monitoring.frequency: At presentation; repeat if clinical change
monitoring.action: If papilledema: urgent LP for opening pressure; MRV to exclude CVT; ophthalmology consult
Adjust treatment plan; reassess diagnosis if not improving at 4-6 weeks

monitoring.item: ECG (if using dopamine antagonists, triptans, or DHE)
monitoring.frequency: Before first dose; repeat if symptoms
monitoring.action: Hold QT-prolonging medications; cardiology consult if QTc >500 ms

disposition.criteria: Pain controlled to tolerable level; able to tolerate PO; no red flags on history or exam; normal neurologic exam; CT head normal (if indicated); reliable patient with clear return precautions; follow-up arranged within 1-2 weeks

Headache unresponsive to ED treatment requiring IV medications; need for IV antibiotic therapy (suspected meningitis); diagnostic workup requiring inpatient monitoring (serial LPs, extended imaging); intractable nausea/vomiting with dehydration; new neurologic deficit under investigation

Suspected SAH with hemodynamic instability or declining mental status; confirmed bacterial meningitis with sepsis or altered consciousness; elevated ICP with risk of herniation; cerebral venous thrombosis with hemorrhagic conversion; status requiring continuous neuro monitoring; hypertensive emergency with neurologic symptoms

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
disposition.criteria: Need for neurosurgical intervention not available (aneurysm clipping/coiling, VP shunt, tumor resection); need for interventional neuroradiology (embolization, thrombectomy); need for continuous EEG monitoring not available locally

New headache without red flags: PCP or neurology within 1-2 weeks; Chronic headache: neurology/headache specialist within 4-6 weeks; After hospitalization: neurology follow-up within 2-4 weeks; After normal ED workup: PCP within 1-2 weeks to review results
